bibl.title: Letter from John W. Ross to [Howard A.] Kelly, November 6, 1907

div1.p: Ross writes to Kelly to clarify his position in regards to an unnamed incident involving Carroll. He stresses that Gorgas was the commanding officer at the time of the incident.

div1.head: Letter from John W. Ross to [Howard A.] Kelly, November 6, 1907
div1.opener:
Copy
Pasadena, California,
November 6, 1907.
Dear Dr. Kelly:-
div1.p:
Please accept my sincere thanks for your favor of the 26th
ultimo. I am very glad indeed that you are writing up the life
of our heroic friend Carroll.

I have no objection to your publishing Carroll's letter,
provided you will introduce the enclosed foot-note which will
prevent any misunderstanding of Guitéras' position, as well as
of my own. The foot-note, referred to, explains itself.

Col. Gorgas, who was our Chief Surgeon at the time, and
on the ground, fully approved of my action in the matter. I
should have included the latter statement in the foot-note but
did not like to do so without first consulting Gorgas. I have
sent him a copy of your letter and of the foot-note; you will
probably hear from him upon the subject. Should you wish to
write to him for further particulars, his address is
Col. W. C. Gorgas, U. S. Army,
Isthmian Canal Commissioner,
Ancon, Canal Zone,
Isthmus of Panama.
Again thanking you for your courtesy, I beg to remain,
div1.closer: Most truly yours, John W. Ross.
